takeaway.headline: NKU is well-positioned to lead: make AI literacy a universal baseline, then build role-based depth across every college.
takeaway.subhead: Multiple high-credibility labor market and government sources show AI capability is becoming a cross-discipline expectation—not just a tech specialty. The highest-impact approach is a shared foundation (AI literacy + data literacy + responsible use) paired with job-family pathways (power-user, builder, and high-stakes governance).
executiveNotes: This dashboard combines near–real-time job-posting signals (Indeed Hiring Lab) with authoritative government frameworks for occupations and skills (U.S. BLS and U.S. Department of Labor/O*NET).

Job postings provide a leading indicator of employer demand; BLS and O*NET provide durable context for workforce planning, occupation definitions, and skill language that translates cleanly to curriculum.

usajobsPulse.note: Missing USAJOBS_API_KEY / USAJOBS_USER_AGENT. Add as GitHub Secrets to enable this lens.

onetHotTechnologies.note: Could not fetch O*NET Hot Technologies CSV from the standard export URL. If this persists, we’ll switch to pulling from O*NET Web Services or pinning a downloaded CSV in-repo.

coreSkills.title: AI literacy & professional judgment
coreSkills.desc: What AI can/can’t do, where it fails, and how to verify outputs—so graduates use AI confidently, responsibly, and with appropriate human oversight.

coreSkills.title: Prompting + iteration (workplace productivity)
coreSkills.desc: Turning ambiguous work into clear instructions: constraints, examples, critique loops, and simple evaluation criteria to produce higher-quality results faster.

coreSkills.title: Data literacy (the engine behind AI value)
coreSkills.desc: Data quality, privacy basics, measurement, experimentation, and interpreting outputs—skills that make AI adoption safer and measurably useful.

coreSkills.title: Responsible AI & governance readiness
coreSkills.desc: Bias and fairness awareness, privacy/security implications, transparency expectations, documentation habits, and responsible escalation paths.

coreSkills.title: Human skills amplified by AI
coreSkills.desc: Problem framing, communication, domain context, ethical reasoning, and stakeholder alignment—what differentiates high-impact graduates in AI-enabled workplaces.

aiMentionsTrend.title: AI mentions in job postings continue to rise (Indeed Hiring Lab — Indeed AI Tracker)
aiMentionsTrend.note: These values are placeholders for the visual trend line until exact points are transcribed from the Indeed AI Tracker chart. The key anchor point reflected here is 4.2% of U.S. job postings mentioning AI in Dec 2025, as reported by Indeed Hiring Lab (Jan 22, 2026).
aiMentionsTrend.whyItMatters: This is a leading indicator: employer language is changing now, which typically precedes curriculum and workforce shifts. It supports scaling baseline AI literacy beyond tech majors.

aiMentionsByFamily.title: AI mentions differ by job family (Dec 2025 snapshot, Indeed Hiring Lab)
aiMentionsByFamily.note: From Indeed Hiring Lab’s Jan 22, 2026 U.S. Labor Market Update. These percentages represent the share of postings within each listed job family that mention AI (not the share of all postings).
aiMentionsByFamily.whyItMatters: This supports an NKU strategy of ‘foundation + pathways’: everyone gets baseline readiness, while programs tailor depth based on how AI shows up in that discipline’s work.

aiOutsideITShare.title: AI demand extends beyond IT/CS (benchmark from job-posting analytics)
aiOutsideITShare.note: This split is widely cited from private job-posting analytics (Lightcast). Treat as a benchmark placeholder unless NKU has access to the underlying Lightcast report/data. Government sources (BLS/O*NET) provide authoritative occupation and skill taxonomies but do not publish this exact IT vs non-IT posting split.
aiOutsideITShare.whyItMatters: Even as a benchmark, it reinforces a key executive message: AI-readiness is an institution-wide priority, not a single-department initiative.

Non-technical: AI-assisted workflow design (SOPs + QA checklists) to standardize quality and reduce rework
Tool evaluation (capabilities, cost, risk, governance) to make informed adoption decisions
Data-informed decision making and impact measurement to track outcomes, not hype
Change management and stakeholder communication to implement AI responsibly and effectively
Technical: LLM integration patterns (RAG, tool use, evaluation) to build reliable AI-enabled systems
Testing and evaluation (quality, bias, robustness) to ensure performance and reduce risk
Monitoring and lifecycle (drift, feedback, incident response) to maintain trust over time
Security and privacy engineering fundamentals to protect sensitive data and comply with policy
High-stakes: Risk assessment + controls (auditability, oversight) aligned to compliance and policy needs
Documentation (decision logs, transparency) to support review, explainability, and accountability
Fairness/bias evaluation and mitigation to reduce harm and support equitable outcomes
Escalation paths and human-in-the-loop review to manage exceptions and high-impact decisions

methodology.whatThisDashboardIs: A decision-support snapshot for NKU leaders that translates credible labor-market signals into clear curriculum and program implications.
howToReadTheSignals: Indeed Hiring Lab job-posting analysis provides near-real-time employer language and trend direction (a leading indicator).
BLS adds authoritative workforce planning context and projection methodology used nationally for occupations and employment outlook.
O*NET (U.S. Department of Labor) provides standardized occupation and skill language that can be mapped to course outcomes and program competencies.
Private analytics (Lightcast) can add benchmarking depth when NKU has access to full reports; when not available, treat as illustrative context and label as such.
recommendedUse: Use these signals to prioritize cross-college baseline outcomes for AI literacy and data literacy.
Use job-family differences to justify targeted electives, certificates, and applied project pathways.
Use O*NET language to align curriculum outcomes to nationally recognized skill and occupation terminology.

sources.name: Indeed Hiring Lab (High-credibility job-posting analysis) — January 22, 2026 U.S. Labor Market Update: AI tracker trend and job-family breakout (e.g., 4.2% in Dec 2025; Data & Analytics, Marketing, HR examples)

U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) — Monthly Labor Review (peer-reviewed BLS publication): Incorporating AI impacts in BLS employment projections (2025). Authoritative workforce planning context and methodology.
U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) — TED: The Economics Daily (official BLS publication): AI impacts in BLS employment projections (2025). Executive-friendly summary of BLS projection work.

U.S. Department of Labor — O*NET Resource Center (official): ‘What’s New’ updates and standardized occupation/skill language, including Hot Technologies and in-demand technology skill signals (Dec 2025 update referenced).

Lightcast (private labor-market analytics) — Global AI skills outlook research landing page. Use for benchmarking only when NKU has access to the underlying report/data that supports specific numeric claims.
